ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Nada
Some asynchronous recorded lectures.
3/5 days during the week were synchronous Zoom classes, while the other two days we were given asynchronous assignments or they were used for live tests and quizzes.
synchronous and asynchronous small seminars every week (MWF Synchronous, and TTh Asynchronous with occasional examinations on the asynchronous days.
It was often a discussion but sometimes the professor lectured about a certain subject.
Live virtual class that was also very discussion based

We had virtual class 3 days a week, some times it was lecture and sometimes it was more discussion based. We had asynchronous activities 2 days a week. These activities were usually either watching recorded lectures, reading stories, watching short films, or doing worksheets.
office hours, vhl online homework

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Spanish I guess?
I developed my knowledge and fluency in Spanish.

I learned the important skill of how to feel comfortable speaking to other people in a different language. I also gained a deeper understanding of the spanish language in terms of grammar and vocabulary and how to connect those two.

Well, the class was taught completely in Spanish so there was constant immersion and a certain amount of commonplace interaction that you had to do, ranging from saying hello and casually chatting about a weekend to discussing intricacies of assignments and grammar concepts. Also, the huge of amount of exposure that we had to media, our professor, and recommended outside content was really nice for developing a instinctual idea of how the language structure works, how it sounds, and mannerisms that might be different from English. It was also my first semester, so it was a nice introduction to how Spanish classes and classes in general work at Yale.
Development of Spanish grammar, vocabulary, and fluidity in both speaking and writing.

I learned a ton about Spanish vocabulary, grammar, and speaking/writing skills. The content was very rich, all the way from reviewing basic grammar rules to advanced structures. I also learned a decent amount about Spanish culture and gained exposure to a bunch of stories, books, and movies.
I developed new vocabulary from the chapters, learned the difference between many new verb tenses, and obtained a greater understanding for the Spanish language.
My Spanish writing and speaking skills improved tremendously. I am now able to hold a conversation with someone for a bit and write a page or two in Spanish that is halfway decent.
lots of spanish! better at speaking and writing

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: They cut the in-person instruction down from five days to three, but still tried to fit in the same amount of material. I don't think I could ever learn Spanish just on my own. They should go back to five days a week of instruction, or reduce the amount of stuff we're supposed to learn by 40%.

I think it's really hard to teach language over Zoom. I think having discussion in breakout rooms frequently was useful, but it's hard to simulate the level of engagement we get from in person learning. I found the class to be relatively well organized, although at times it seemed to move a bit fast. It was frustrating having the exams so focused on writing, rather than grammar and vocabulary directly. They felt a bit redundant with the compositions.

The strengths of the course this year was the information on grammar. Some weaknesses are not having group discussions out of breakout groups. It could have been improved by maybe talking together as a class.

Strengths: The class was taught completely in Spanish so you were immersed in thinking and communicating using the language. That also means you figure out how to have casual conversations, do a bit of analysis, and sort out confusions or questions using the language, which was a good skill to work on. Because the class met or had assignments so often, you really start to get an instinct for how to speak and write in the language. The every-other-day structure for synchronous and asynchronous classes worked really well for maintaining a sense of engagement in the class while having time to do work and reflect on new content. All the students in the class were also super easy to work with, and we were given plenty of opportunities to work together in breakout rooms and get to know everyone else in the class. Most of the semester we had daily homework and we were provided an excess amount of resources for any given unit or lesson, so there was always work to do, but it was always manageable. 
Weaknesses: If you don't prepare a little bit, the transition into the class in the first few weeks can be a bit difficult. Having to communicate the source of misunderstandings or things that were unclear can be a bit difficult. My experience with the professor in these first few weeks was a bit up and down because of this obstacles and some lack of transparency.

Strengths - Consistent practice of the Spanish language in order to learn quickly and effectively. Some enjoyable readings and movies scattered throughout the class. Great professors!

Weaknesses - Homework can be time-consuming and monotonous as there are assigned homework every night. Grading can be tough. Large time commitment.

The strength was definitely the consistent schedule and how there was work almost everyday. This made the course's pace very smooth and I felt like I was learning a bit every day. My professor (Diaz) was also so kind and always available to talk or answer questions.

This course had many strengths, including its variety of course material that always kept the students engaged and focused. It could be improved by doing more group activity in which students had to speak in front of everyone to test their oral skills.

Strengths: Class was usually enjoyable as the professor used a lot of breakout rooms to make the work collaborative. If you put in the work you will improve a lot. I got a lot of helpful feedback on compositions that I wrote.

Weakness: The asynchronous activities were sometimes unhelpful. A lot of times powerpoints and worksheets were posted for you to click through or do, and this wasn't very engaging. Additionally, a lot of material was posted on these days, which felt overwhelming. 

Improvements: I think posting less files on the asynchronous days would help. I also thinking making most of the asynchronous activities centered around reading stories, watching short films, or other Spanish media would be the best use of that time.
this is naturally a hard course and was challenging so just knowing that you have to put the time in to receive is all. great course!!

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I feel like we rarely got the right balance of breakout rooms. We either never went to breakout rooms, which I thought was just a wasted class when it came to trying to learn a language, or we spent the whole class in a breakout room with another student, which got stale after a bit and I felt like I wasn't getting enough instruction. So we could have struck a better balance.
Breakout rooms were a success. I didn't find the asynchronous lectures particularly useful. In general I think the more interactive the better.

The breakout rooms succeeded mostly in that it created more of a comfortable environment between students and created some relationships that students could use outside of class to ask for help in the class.

Zoom lessons and activities actually felt really smooth and natural in this class. Breakout rooms worked really well for pair or group work, screen sharing worked fine for teaching concepts, and the professor did a good job of engaging the class. Of course, screen-sharing didn't really work well for showing videos to the class, but there wasn't much need for that anyway so it wasn't a big issue.
asynchronous activities were helpful as they could be done whenever. Meeting 3 days a week made the class more managable.

Having live lectures only three times a week was very helpful and having all tests at the same time made it easy for scheduling. Breakout rooms were utilized very well and I got to talk to each one of my classmates through Zoom.

The asynchronous days were a success, because everyone was held accountable for completing the work that was clearly laid out for us on the syllabus and in class because the material would be the focus of the next synchronous day. The synchronous lectures were always lively and fun to attend. Although, the format of each synchronous lesson only fluctuated between 2 different ways of learning: being lectured in the big Zoom or being able to talk with a partner in a breakout room. This is just an overall characteristic of online learning that I'm not sure could have been altered either way.

I think using breakout rooms in class a lot really functioned well and made the class more enjoyable and productive. I think the asynchronous activities were usually not engaging. As I said in the previous question: I think making most of the asynchronous activities centered around reading stories, watching short films, or other Spanish media would be a better use of that time than doing worksheets or clicking through powerpoints.
I wish I could meet everyone in person but covid is covid

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think there are probably better ways to learn Spanish.
Yes, it's effective, nothing flashy.
Yes, even though it was kind of difficult, it was rewarding in that I feel that my spanish and my ability to speak it to others has greatly improved.

Yes, overall the class was pretty well-organized and I felt like I grew a lot. First of all, I was pretty nervous coming into the class because I didn't really know what to expect and worried it would be really intense or I'd get lost, and that simply wasn't the case - by the end of the semester, I felt like I had a good grasp of expectations, understood the professor's style of teaching, and really enjoyed the class environment. At the same, I had some difficulty with the professor and understanding the assignments at the start of the semester. Getting in touch with other students was super helpful, and any real issues I had worked themselves out over time, so, to reiterate, yes I would recommend the class because it was really good for improving at the language and the class itself was fun, but that also comes with relatively daily work and a potentially challenging introduction to the format of the class.

Needed for the language requirement at yale, this course isn't easy but you will learn. I would recommend this course to someone interested in learning Spanish who is looking to become more proficient in both speaking and writing.

Yes! The professor and the content made this a great course to take. Tests were quite hard and there is a lot of work but for someone just looking to take a Spanish class for credit, it was definitely the right choice!

Yes, I would recommend this course to another student if they have sufficient background in the language. I got placed into this course as a first year based on my past high school Spanish level and I felt like it was the perfect placement for me.

I know most people take this course for a language requirement and so they don't really have a choice whether or not to take this course. That said, I would recommend this course to a motivated student who is interested in Spanish. You have to be ready to work hard in this course, but if you do, you will improve a lot.
Yes!!! Diaz is a great profesor and really wants his students to succeed. Yes this requires a lot of outside studying to review and maintain spanish skill but overall 10/10
